awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Smart Protection for DC Power Systems: Distributed and Proactive Approach
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this CAREER project is to provide intelligent solutions for the protection of DC power systems, which is one of the major barriers that prevent the wide usage of DC power systems. DC power systems have received renewed attention due to a number of advantages they offer such as easy renewable energy resource integration, high-efficiency long distance transmission, and simpler interface with power electronics converters. Applications including microgrids with distributed generators, bulk power transmission, and low-voltage distribution systems have been investigated. Compared to the control aspects of DC systems that have made sizable progress, system protection has always been a challenge. The research in this project will address protection issues for DC power systems, which will contribute to strengthen this important aspect of DC power systems and can have impact in various applications. The outcomes of this research will be disseminated through presentations and publications and can be readily utilized in conjunction with other aspects of distributed and/or sustainable energy applications using DC power to generate synergistic effects on overall system reliability improvement. Furthermore, this CAREER project will academically and financially support graduate students and nurture them to prepare them as part of the next generation of multidisciplinary researchers and engineers. The project will also provide ample research opportunities to undergraduate students.

While the advantages of DC power systems are great, the protection aspects of these systems have posed many challenges such as effectively breaking a DC arc, autonomously locating a fault within a microgrid, DC protective equipment, and certainly the lack of standards, guidelines and experience. Although protection technology for AC systems has a long history and maturity, it is difficult to directly apply these to DC systems because of the non-alternating nature and fast dynamics of DC power. Hence, the protection of DC power systems needs to take a fundamentally different approach than that of existing AC technologies. Furthermore, complex modern power systems need more intelligence for their operation. In this CAREER project, a distributed and proactive approach will be taken as the project aims to provide a protection framework with swift fault current interruption, accurate fault location, and distributed decision-making based on various system parameters. The protection framework development will contain integrated components for fast responses and compound decisions based on multi-dimensional intelligence. The successful execution of this CAREER project will contribute to the implementation of modern power systems that take advantage of DC power. The activities will result in multidisciplinary research as well as educational impacts, and will provide interesting and useful applications of advanced artificial intelligence, control and communication technologies to the power and energy system area.
org_div_long_name: Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE REGENTS OF THE UNIV. OF COLORADO

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this CAREER project is to provide intelligent solutions for a smart DC power system which incorporates intelligent system automation. A smart power system includes optimal energy management in normal condition and fast responding self-healing capability during fault which improves the efficiency, reliability, security, and sustainability of the system. 

In this project, the target microgrid system has been divided into three layers: higher energy management layer, middle multi-agent-system (MAS) layer, and lower power handling layer. The focus of this project is on the multi-dimensional integration of various control and optimization techniques through communications making intelligent decisions. We are trying to contribute to developing related theories and practical techniques to bring it up to a completely realizable level. 

(i) EMS layer: Research has been focused on developing a distributed and cooperative transactive energy management platform, especially considering the dynamic and efficient operation from the economic standpoint. Optimal pricing algorithms in distributed and privacy-preserving manners have been investigated for smart grid operation, ensuring the maximum economic beneﬁts for system stakeholders. Some of the outcomes in the areas include distributed energy trading methods voltage and congestion management using a distributed consensus algorithm, peer-to-peer (P2P) market paradigm and pricing strategy for energy sharing between multiple microgrids and utility grid for proactive prosumers to implement transactive energy systems. Moreover, interface with middle MAS layer and lower control layer for communication constraints and load restoration strategy in networked systems, respectively. (ii) MAS layer: Distributed autonomous operation of MAS in DC microgrid systems has been investigated. Techniques to integrate the DC microgrid system with the Ethernet-based MAS using JADE?s remote agent management capabilities and to exchange data between various controllable elements in a distributed manner for intelligent decision making have been developed, as well as a novel method that gives more freedom in terms of sudden changes and events allowing more ﬂexibility and robustness. (iii) Control layer: One of the outcomes in this area is developing insights on stability issues due to the negative incremental resistance exhibited by constant power loads (CPLs) for DC microgrid systems with power electronics converters. For the overall stability of the system with CPLs, a simplified small-signal model has been developed and a variable inductor-based dynamic stabilizer is proposed in order to enhance the stability margin of DC microgrids and guarantee stable operation. Another line of outcome of this project is to investigate the feasibility of actual neural-network in an embedded hadware for dynamic system control, which shows a good performance for a real-time dynamic system identification using a deep neural network.

Three Ph.D., one M.S., and two undergraduate students have engaged in this project. All graduate students have earned their degree with the ourcomes of their research in this project. Seven journal papers, 18 conference presentations, two Ph.D. dissertations, and a M.S. thesis were delivered to desseminate the research outcomes. The team also have participated in several outreach events for K-12 students.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 04/19/2022
Modified by: Jae-Do Park
